Summary Since I was a child, I had a strong vocation in technology, the same that inspires every day scientists, engineers, while exploring our Universe or just understanding how things work. 
 
Software engineering is my daily bread, creating scalable, reliable architectures is the foundation of my daily job, the spark that spins me up in the morning. 
 
I’ve spent the majority of my work life between being a Software Engineer for embedded or large scale systems, and a Site Reliability Engineer (SRE), running services at scale, and making them scale even more. 
 
I have a strong leadership vocation and love working in challenging environments as individual contributor of a team. Summary I've recently finished my PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of British Columbia. My advisor was Matei Ripeanu, and I worked in the NetSysLab.  
 
My research focused on automating the configuration of intermediate storage systems.  
I was also involved in the Totem project (Graph Processing in Hybrid Architectures).  
 
 
Past: 
 
During the summers of 2009, 2010, and 2013 I had a great time at Google as an intern for the Site Reliability Engineering team for ContentAds (2009), and as Software Engineer intern for the Cluster Management team (2010), and the Google Feedback team (2013) in Mountain View, CA, USA.  
 
Before starting at UBC, I worked at the LSD (Distributed Systems Lab) of UFCG (Universidade Federal de Campina Grande) in Brazil where I worked as software engineer and assistant researcher (2006-2008), and I concluded my undergraduate (2003) and MSc studies (2005) contributing to OurGrid project. As part of my research in OurGrid, I undertook an internship at Hewlett Packard Labs in Palo Alto, CA, USA. In 2008, I was also an intern at Fraunhofer ITWM in Kaiserslautern, Germany contributing to their Jawari project for three months. Summary I'm a Computer Engineering PhD working on the Ganeti virtualization cluster management software at Google. 
 
During my PhD I worked on languages, virtual machines and code transformation for exploiting modern computer architectures and, in particular, my PhD thesis was on machine learning techniques applied to compilers. 
 
As a side topic, I also did research on multiagent systems to manage electrical power networks. 
 
My coding experience includes working on four different compilers (LLVM, GCC, ILDJIT, Petabricks) and implementing a code generator for ARM processors as part of the backend of ILDJIT. 
I designed and implemented from scratch a semantic search engine for finding related concepts inside a set of documents even if they are expressed with different words.  
I contributed code to an opensource CMS (FlatNuke).  
I also worked on many other personal or university-related smaller projects, and as a webmaster for several websites. 
 
I’ve worked extensively with the following languages: C, C++, Python, Java, ASP classic, Visual Basic, Bash Scripting.  
I also have basic knowledge of C# and PHP. 
 
Other interests of mine include operating systems, artificial intelligence and web programming. 
 
During the university time, I was a member of the Politecnico di Milano "Tower of Hanoi" team, participating in various international computer security competitions.

Summary I have background in computer science and mathematics and have experience in software engineering, especially design and implementation of parallel algorithms for computationally demanding numerical problems on CPU clusters (MPI) and on GPU (CUDA).
